video.title: Still Wakes the Deep | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

The Chinese Room is actually a British developer, 
which initially struck me as weird and possibly

racist but then I thought, wait, it&#39;d be even 
weirder if they were called The British Room.

I&#39;m trying to picture a British room and all 
I&#39;m seeing is the waiting area of a grimy fish

and chip shop with a busted TV in the corner 
permanently tuned to an episode of Countdown.

The Chinese Room has brought us such games as 
Dear Esther, Everybody&#39;s Gone To The Rapture and

Amnesia: A Machine For Pigs, and I played their 
new game Still Wakes The Deep because I wanted

to see if they&#39;ve finally remembered to put some 
actual video game mechanics in their video game.

Probably shouldn&#39;t hold out too much hope since 
they can&#39;t even remember what fucking nationality

they are, but how did they do this time? Well, 
there&#39;s some instant death stealth sequences,

some quick time events, aaand you climb 
on ledges a bit. Hey, getting better. Oop,

hang on, all the things you can climb 
on are coloured vibrant yellow. Ah,

there it is. Truly the Chinese Room have finally 
got their finger on the pulse of modern game

design standards. Give them fifteen more years 
and maybe they&#39;ll figure out combat mechanics.

I&#39;m just weedling your winkie, Chinese Room, 
I know walking sims can be a perfectly valid

form of interactive storytelling and they&#39;re a 
hell of a lot less work than wiring up a movie

projector to a treadmill, so let&#39;s focus on the 
story. Still Walks Down Corridors centres on Caz,

a brash two-fisted Scotsman who&#39;d probably deck 
the shite out of the protagonist of Dear Esther

for being a moony-eyed self-pitying cunt. He&#39;s 
working as an electrician on a North Sea oil rig

when some rozzers show up looking to arrest him 
for decking the shite out of too many people on

the mainland, but just as he&#39;s about to board 
the helicopter and begin his new life decking

the shite out of kiddie fiddlers in the prison 
showers, a thing happens. And by that I mean,

THE thing happens. John Carpenter&#39;s The Thing. 
The oil drillers hit something weird and alien

under the sea that&#39;s either extremely 
hostile to human beings or extremely,

boundary-crossingly fond of them and so the 
game&#39;s all &quot;Psych! You thought this was a Ken

Loach-style gritty realism story about the plight 
of the working class in contemporary Britain,

it&#39;s actually a sci fi horror game! Or possibly a 
horror sci fi game. In either case, don&#39;t hold out

hope for the life expectancy of anyone you talk 
to over a phone in the next four hours or so.

Caz must find a way to escape the oil rig, 
harassed at every turn by malfunctioning

technology, collapsing infrastructure, mutated 
friends and very difficult to understand accents.

Don&#39;t worry, though, the subtitles have your 
back. Someone&#39;ll go &quot;Ach I cannae goo that way

you wee numpty shite,&quot; and the subtitles will 
say &quot;Oh dear I cannot go in that direction you

small stupid person faeces.&quot; I don&#39;t know why this 
makes me laugh so much. I mean, I have got roots

up north but surely the Scottish aren&#39;t so hard to 
understand you need subtitles? Just pay attention

to context. If in doubt, assume they&#39;re saying 
whatever would be the most violently aggressive

thing to say in that moment. So since the story 
is the important part of a ghost train ride it&#39;s

worth stating that the story in Still Wanks 
The Dialogue Writer is pretty damn solid. Over

the course of about four or five hours we get a 
strong sense of continuity watching the oil rig

gradually fall apart as it increasingly succumbs 
to the alien entity and the last survivors get

whittled down. Caz is a vocal and relatable 
presence behind the camera who gets more and

more believably exasperated every time someone in 
a nice cozy saferoom tells him he has to navigate

a darkened pipe labyrinth and pull whatever lever 
will ostensibly prolong his existence this time.

I like the way the prologue has us interact with 
everyone on the rig as they go about their daily

lives, effectively establishing this small, 
enclosed community where everyone&#39;s had to

shower together and hold up a towel to 
let someone else discreetly masturbate

at some point. It means every corpse we find is 
someone we and Caz know with a name and a face,

so it has actual impact, in contrast to something 
like Doom 3 where disaster strikes and anonymous

bodies pop out of every cupboard like they were 
stuffed in there as a prank. My criticism of

the story is that a lot of what it sets up it 
seems to ditch unceremoniously. Characters have

a tendency to drop dead at the point when the 
plot needs them to and not for any adequately

explored reason. Even what passes for the main 
villain just spontaneously dies at the end of

their last chase sequence without Caz having 
to do anything, unless it&#39;s because he broke

wind in some unfathomably spectacular way. 
We also never really gain any understanding

of what the alien entity is as it destroys our 
lives, but I&#39;m choosing to interpret that as a

rather on the nose metaphor for the struggle 
of the working poor in Thatcher&#39;s Britain.

On the whole I like Still Weeps The Dank when 
it&#39;s being an interactive horror movie, I like it

a lot less when it&#39;s being a video game. There&#39;s 
a couple of moments the game slams on the brakes

and refuses to let you leave the room until you 
turn on an electric heater and warm your hands,

so I wonder if at one point this was part of 
some Cryostasis-style body heat mechanic that got

ditched and now all that remains of it are these 
slightly obnoxious forced tea breaks, but what I

really wanna complain about is the token stealth. 
You&#39;ll know when you get to the first stealth bit

&#39;cos you&#39;ll creep into a dark area where something 
alive and horrible is making upsetting noises and

some fucking text will pop up saying &quot;Remember, 
you can throw objects to distract monsters!&quot; And

I was like &quot;Well, so much for fucking suspense, 
eh, game. You&#39;ve just given away two things:

one, there&#39;s definitely a monster in the room, 
and two, it&#39;s a complete fucking numpty.&quot; Not

that that stopped me dying about five times 
to it thanks to poor lighting, inadequately

explained visibility mechanics and the monster in 
question being such an anatomical disaster area

it was hard to tell if it was looking at 
me or stealing the milk out of the fridge.

And besides that gameplay-wise it&#39;s mostly one 
glorified quick time event after another. Maybe

I deserve some of the blame for shit like 
this and Hellblade 2&#39;s sucky-bum combat.

Critics and players are always giving walking 
simulators shit for not being real games,

much as I did a few minutes ago, and the end 
result is story focused games that feel like

they have to tokenly acknowledge standard gameplay 
to please everyone, but if you&#39;re just gonna pop

your head into a combat/stealth mechanic for 
five minutes at a time without making it a

core part of the experience then I&#39;d prefer you 
stayed in your fucking lane. There are games with

completely linear narratives that I like. 
Beginner&#39;s Guide. Doki Doki Literature Club.

Before Your Eyes. I found that really emotionally 
effective and doubt it would&#39;ve been much improved

by having to occasionally stop to have a shootout 
with drug dealers. Then again, Hellblade 2 and

Still Works The Shaft are both horror games, and 
such things kinda need at least some threat to the

player to maximise effectiveness, so I&#39;m not even 
sure what I&#39;m asking for, now. I guess a greater

commitment to what gameplay mechanics they do 
have, and another excuse to use the word &quot;numpty.&quot;
